comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/] Thanks for posting this! The previous 'Koenigin Luise' was a regular visitor to Australia for the North German Lloyd Company. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_K%C3%B6nigin_Luise_(1896)

comment.author: 15088225@N07
comment._content: I have the SS Omar in my documentary as she passes Cocos Island and it's too rough to "drop a barrel". Another time I have her dropping off kittens in a barrel! Thanks for posting, it's good to see her close-up. Description about the barrels here: classic-yacht.asn.au/wp-content/uploads/CYAA-Mag-FEB-2010...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmmm, wasn't Fort Macquarie demolished in 1901? The photographer was born in 1901...and yet that really does look like Fort Macquarie.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] Yes, Fort Macquarie was demolished in 1901,  and the new tramway sheds had a castellated outline and a castle tower.  See this wonderful 1906 (?) photo (which needs further research) - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5168027276/]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Of course! GREYCLIFFE at the tram depot d'oh! How could we forget that important detail?! :P
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
